body:
Landry of Paris

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search
Saint Landry of Paris
Statue of St. Landry, Église Saint-Germain-l'Auxerrois, Paris
Died c. 661
Venerated in Roman Catholic Church
Feast 10 June

Saint Landry (Landericus) of Paris (died c. 661) was a bishop of Paris and is recognized as a saint by the Roman Catholic Church. Landry built a hospital dedicated to St. Christopher, which later became the Hôtel-Dieu de Paris . His feast day is 10 June.

Contents

  • 1 Life
  • 2 Veneration
  • 3 References
  • 4 External links

Life [ edit ]

Landry was chief clerk of the Royal Chancery. In 650, he succeeded Audobertus as Bishop of Paris. [1] During the famine of 650-51, Bishop Landry sold all of his personal possessions, as well as some of the furniture and sacred vessels of the church, to feed the poor. [2]

He is credited with building the first major hospital in the city, dedicating it to Saint Christopher , (now the Hôtel-Dieu). [3]

In 653, Landry, with 23 other bishops, subscribed to the charter Clovis II gave to Saint-Denis Abbey , exempting it from episcopal jurisdiction. It is believed that he built the original church of Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois , which became the parish church of the kings of France. [3]

He died in 661. [3]

Veneration [ edit ]

Eglise Saint-Landry, c.1810

He was buried at the Church of Saint-Germain-l'Auxerrois, where there is a chapel named after him and most of his relics are kept, except for two bones that were given to the parish of Saint-Landry in 1408, which was originally a chapel near the saint’s house in which he was accustomed to pray. He is honored with an office in the new Paris Breviary. [1]

His feast day is 10 June. [1]

Miracles were recorded of him. One of them reads:

We have seen and known that a man which men call Raoul Gracard was smitten suddenly, and had the head much great and swollen, and was so red in the face of him that all folk that saw him deemed and held him for a leper . Which man with great haste came to the presence of Saint Landry, and there he confessed him much devoutly, receiving much benignly his penance, and after he came to the sudary of the saint and with great devotion kissed it, and when he had done his offering and vow with much great faith and hope he returned, and unnethe [hardly] he was come to his house when he became as whole as ever he was.

— Jacob de Voragine , The Golden Legend, [4]

St. Landry Catholic Church , in Opelousas, Louisiana is dedicated to Landry of Paris. [5] A statue of Saint Landry stands behind the altar, and a stained glass window with his image on the southwest end of the church. [ citation needed ]

Port St-Landry was Paris' first dock. [6]

References [ edit ]

  1. ^ a b c Butler, Alban. "St. Landry, Bishop of Paris, Confessor", The Lives of the Saints . 1866 This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the public domain .
  2. ^ "About our Patron, St. Landry", St. Landry Catholic Church, Opelousa, Louisiana
  3. ^ a b c Harper, John N., "There are four saints named Landry in Catholicism. Who was ours?", Daily Advertiser , November 4, 2013
  4. ^ The Golden Legend: The Life of Saint Landry Archived 2007-08-20 at the Wayback Machine
  5. ^ Hambrick, Keith S., Review of "The Mother Church of Acadiana", Louisiana History , Louisiana Historical Association, Vol. 36, No. 3 (Summer, 1995), pp. 365-368
  6. ^ Michelin Green Guide Paris , Michelin Travel & Lifestyle, 2011 ISBN 9782067182202

External links [ edit ]

  • Saints of the Day, June 10: Landericus (Landry) of Paris at SaintPatrickDC.org

Landry of Paris - Wikipedia Landry of Paris From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Jump to navigation Jump to search Saint Landry of Paris Statue of St. Landry, Église Saint-Germain-l'Auxerrois, Paris Died c. 661 Venerated in Roman Catholic Church Feast 10 June Saint Landry (Landericus) of Paris (died c. 661) was a bishop of Paris and is recognized as a saint by the Roman Catholic Church. Landry built a hospital dedicated to St. Christopher, which later became the Hôtel-Dieu de Paris . His feast day is 10 June. Contents 1 Life 2 Veneration 3 References 4 External links Life [ edit ] Landry was chief clerk of the Royal Chancery. In 650, he succeeded Audobertus as Bishop of Paris. [1] During the famine of 650-51, Bishop Landry sold all of his personal possessions, as well as some of the furniture and sacred vessels of the church, to feed the poor. [2] He is credited with building the first major hospital in the city, dedicating it to Saint Christopher , (now the Hôtel-Dieu). [3] In 653, Landry, with 23 other bishops, subscribed to the charter Clovis II gave to Saint-Denis Abbey , exempting it from episcopal jurisdiction. It is believed that he built the original church of Saint-Germain l'Auxerrois , which became the parish church of the kings of France. [3] He died in 661. [3] Veneration [ edit ] Eglise Saint-Landry, c.1810 He was buried at the Church of Saint-Germain-l'Auxerrois, where there is a chapel named after him and most of his relics are kept, except for two bones that were given to the parish of Saint-Landry in 1408, which was originally a chapel near the saint’s house in which he was accustomed to pray. He is honored with an office in the new Paris Breviary. [1] His feast day is 10 June. [1] Miracles were recorded of him.  One of them reads: We have seen and known that a man which men call Raoul Gracard was smitten suddenly, and had the head much great and swollen, and was so red in the face of him that all folk that saw him deemed and held him for a leper .  Which man with great haste came to the presence of Saint Landry, and there he confessed him much devoutly, receiving much benignly his penance, and after he came to the sudary of the saint and with great devotion kissed it, and when he had done his offering and vow with much great faith and hope he returned, and unnethe [hardly] he was come to his house when he became as whole as ever he was. — Jacob de Voragine , The Golden Legend, [4] St. Landry Catholic Church , in Opelousas, Louisiana is dedicated to Landry of Paris. [5] A statue of Saint Landry stands behind the altar, and a stained glass window with his image on the southwest end of the church. [ citation needed ] Port St-Landry was Paris' first dock.
